results.content: Doesn't appear to be well organized yet and the instructor doesn't cover key concepts of the framework prior to diving directly into making a static HTML page. That is better saved for an HTML/CSS or Bootstrap course.

results.content:
This is about as bad as an online course can be. It was obviously done quickly and cheaply.
1. It is acceptable for a video to force the watcher to pause, in order to code along with the instructor. But it is not acceptable to force the user to REWIND, which this course does because when the instructor finishes typing something, he frequently instantly changes to another window without warning. 
2. The instructor is constantly making coding mistakes, but he doesn't have the sense to re-record that part of the video and not make the mistake. Instead, he keeps the recorder running while he puzzles out what's going wrong. The viewer can usually see what the mistake is right away, but we are forced to watch while he figures it out. I can only surmise that this guy doesn't know how to edit videos.
3. Some videos end literally in mid-sentence. Then the next "lecture" begins with the second half of the sentence. 
4. Every lesson begins with a LONG process of installing and configuring various tools. This never goes well the first time. There are always errors. It is an EXHAUSTING process to even get to the point where the student can start coding.
5. The instructor doesn't know the subject matter. He repeatedly makes the mistake of double-registering his controllers: once in the HTML and then again in a route.
results.content_html:
This is about as bad as an online course can be. It was obviously done quickly and cheaply.
1. It is acceptable for a video to force the watcher to pause, in order to code along with the instructor. But it is not acceptable to force the user to REWIND, which this course does because when the instructor finishes typing something, he frequently instantly changes to another window without warning.
2. The instructor is constantly making coding mistakes, but he doesn't have the sense to re-record that part of the video and not make the mistake. Instead, he keeps the recorder running while he puzzles out what's going wrong. The viewer can usually see what the mistake is right away, but we are forced to watch while he figures it out. I can only surmise that this guy doesn't know how to edit videos.
3. Some videos end literally in mid-sentence. Then the next "lecture" begins with the second half of the sentence.
4. Every lesson begins with a LONG process of installing and configuring various tools. This never goes well the first time. There are always errors. It is an EXHAUSTING process to even get to the point where the student can start coding.
5. The instructor doesn't know the subject matter. He repeatedly makes the mistake of double-registering his controllers: once in the HTML and then again in a route.

results.content:
Course does not cover Custom Directives topic and the coding style is too immature, author did not follow any programming methods. Author just goes on typing code without giving explanations to what he did.

This is a really good course if you want to learn Frontend AngularJS along with Backend technologies such as Nodejs with some good backend frameworks like Meanjs, SailsJs and mongodb, BUT only on basic level.

This course is 50 percent angular and 50 percent backend. This course not for someone who ONLY wants to learn AngularJs, you will be disappointed as I was. 

I would still suggest the author to teach more about architecturing an app, use proper programming methods such as DRY, cover more grounds on Custom Directives, Angular-clean code.

Thanks
results.content_html:
Course does not cover Custom Directives topic and the coding style is too immature, author did not follow any programming methods. Author just goes on typing code without giving explanations to what he did.

This is a really good course if you want to learn Frontend AngularJS along with Backend technologies such as Nodejs with some good backend frameworks like Meanjs, SailsJs and mongodb, BUT only on basic level.

This course is 50 percent angular and 50 percent backend. This course not for someone who ONLY wants to learn AngularJs, you will be disappointed as I was.

I would still suggest the author to teach more about architecturing an app, use proper programming methods such as DRY, cover more grounds on Custom Directives, Angular-clean code.

Thanks

results.content:
I really enjoyed this course and the projects that we made.  This is my first time playing around with Angular and this course gave me a good understanding of what you can do with Angular.  

I recommend for anyone who wants to start learning Angular.  There are a lot of technologies used to show how Angular apps can be made, but there isn't a lot of depth into any of the specific applications (hence, it's a good beginners course).  

Overall, I highly recommend.  Great instructor.  Great course.  Thanks.
results.content_html:
I really enjoyed this course and the projects that we made. This is my first time playing around with Angular and this course gave me a good understanding of what you can do with Angular.

I recommend for anyone who wants to start learning Angular. There are a lot of technologies used to show how Angular apps can be made, but there isn't a lot of depth into any of the specific applications (hence, it's a good beginners course).

Overall, I highly recommend. Great instructor. Great course. Thanks.

results.content:
This is a good course as many others have said if you want to copy and work with code just given to you. That being said this can be valuable if you already know JS, HTML, CSS, Angular coming in. I learned these technologies before hand and wanted to apply my knowledge with projects and this course gives some good practices and examples to work with. 

I really like Eduonix, their project bases courses are awesome but they should spend more time explaining concepts and work flow rather than just spending the entire tutorial just typing... It will help students more. I hope they read this.

results.content: Pretty good.  You have to have the right perspective when taking this course though - it's ten dollars first of all.  It's also from 2015.  So things will be different.  But what I like about this instructor is that it's not just do this do that, you can see him have to occasionally fix something or look something up.  That is good to see because troubleshooting tips come in handy.  Some courses move faster but it's just do this do that, and you don't ever see a possible issue you will have to work through in real life.

results.content:
I have a basic understanding of AngularJS and have built a couple of apps in it with a PHP back-end.

Wanting to improve on my knowledge of Angular I subscribed to this course, but after going through the fourth section I don't feel like I've learned anything noteworthy. The instructor comes across a bit clumsy, things go wrong all the time because of really basic mistakes and you're stuck watching him debug these things instead of watching a clear and concise tutorial. I'm not saying there's no value to debugging, but not when the mistakes are this basic and oftentimes it's more because of typos or because he forgot to change a value.


A lot of overhead is introduced as well. The first couple of projects use Angular Seed, which doesn't add anything to the actual project. More time is put in deleting stuff from Angular Seed than using anything from it. A lot of time goes into typing (or copy pasting), where I feel it would have been more logical to start the course with the entire HTML-template ready-made and just start with the implementation of Angular. I'm here to learn Angular, not Twitter Bootstrap, Sails or Meanjs. And you won't learn much from it anyway, so it would have been better to just provide the code.

When learning Angular it's very interesting to set up a module, its routing, dependencies and so on. But by using Angular Seed you're just deleting lines from already written code, which is much less instructive.


The Job Directory app is really a mess. Instead of writing code you're constantly copy-pasting stuff and doing find and 'replace alls' on stuff. This could have been great if you went over everything in a structured way, but you don't. Add to that that the Meanjs project has changed so much since the video was recorded that it's basically useless. There's also no installation instructions for other platforms than Windows (Although I've added some in the comments for El Capitan), so you're on your own for that.


All in all, I think there's better material, from more experienced instructors out there to spend money on.
results.content_html:
I have a basic understanding of AngularJS and have built a couple of apps in it with a PHP back-end.

Wanting to improve on my knowledge of Angular I subscribed to this course, but after going through the fourth section I don't feel like I've learned anything noteworthy. The instructor comes across a bit clumsy, things go wrong all the time because of really basic mistakes and you're stuck watching him debug these things instead of watching a clear and concise tutorial. I'm not saying there's no value to debugging, but not when the mistakes are this basic and oftentimes it's more because of typos or because he forgot to change a value.

A lot of overhead is introduced as well. The first couple of projects use Angular Seed, which doesn't add anything to the actual project. More time is put in deleting stuff from Angular Seed than using anything from it. A lot of time goes into typing (or copy pasting), where I feel it would have been more logical to start the course with the entire HTML-template ready-made and just start with the implementation of Angular. I'm here to learn Angular, not Twitter Bootstrap, Sails or Meanjs. And you won't learn much from it anyway, so it would have been better to just provide the code.

When learning Angular it's very interesting to set up a module, its routing, dependencies and so on. But by using Angular Seed you're just deleting lines from already written code, which is much less instructive.

The Job Directory app is really a mess. Instead of writing code you're constantly copy-pasting stuff and doing find and 'replace alls' on stuff. This could have been great if you went over everything in a structured way, but you don't. Add to that that the Meanjs project has changed so much since the video was recorded that it's basically useless. There's also no installation instructions for other platforms than Windows (Although I've added some in the comments for El Capitan), so you're on your own for that.

All in all, I think there's better material, from more experienced instructors out there to spend money on.

results.content: You will learn some basics about AngularJS but I'm 5 projects in and I feel like all I'm learning is other technologies(MongoDB, NodeJS, Bootstrap , etc) instead of digging into AngularJS.  Granted, the course is call learn AngularJS by creating 10 projects, but you don't learn  enough AngularJS .  I would rather he stays with the same frameworks and just digs into Angular by creating different projects.  I felt like the facebook app didn't teach anything new about angular, just how to use the facebook API.  The teacher is good, and I really want to continue....but I'm not sure I have it in me.  So also take this review that I'm only half way through!

results.content: This lecture is good as a second level lecture.  The instructor doesn't explain the 'why' of things, so you had better learn that elsewhere.  Also, often types so fast and changes pages too quickly so I can't keep up. It helps me learn to debug because i try to stop the video and fix the mistake before he does.  Thanks!
